Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Situation2: A dispatch call sends the ambulance driver through heavy city traffic to a location where a patient has a non-life-threatening injury.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, laughing with my siblings as we tossed around ideas for the weekend—maybe a hike, maybe a movie night. My younger brother looked at me, eyes bright, and said, “You have to come this time. It’s been ages since we all did something together.” I promised I’d try, feeling the warmth of belonging. Just then, my phone buzzed. Dispatch. I was needed for a call—nothing critical, but someone was hurt and waiting. I grabbed my keys, my family’s voices fading behind me. As I slid into the ambulance, the city’s afternoon traffic loomed ahead, thick and slow. I knew I had to drive carefully, keep everyone safe, but the pressure to arrive quickly gnawed at me. My mind raced with the family’s expectation to be present, to be the reliable sibling, and the professional demand to focus, to not let impatience or distraction endanger anyone. My hands tightened on the wheel, heart pulled in two directions, as I tried to steady my breath and decide which role would guide me now.
